sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Janet John)
articles.description: Useful Figma plugins that will help you fix all the little slowdowns and boost your productivity. From color management and image assets to SVG shapes and animation. That’s our new guide to Figma.
articles.title: Useful Figma Plugins And Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lješnjanin)
articles.description: How do we build and establish a successful, bulletproof design system? What’s the state of HTML Email? And what are new, smart interface design patterns we could use? Let’s find out. With our [brand new online workshops](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/) on front-end & design — to help us all boost skills online.
articles.title: New Smashing Workshops on Front-End & Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Don)
articles.description: Often you need two different sets of navigation stacks for pre and post user authentication. Usually, to see more content, you have to be authenticated in some way. Let’s look at how to mount and unmount navigation stack based on a met condition in React Native.
articles.title: Handling Mounting And Unmounting Of Navigation Routes In React Native

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Henrik Fricke)
articles.description: Embedding code examples with third-party scripts often leads to tracking or cookies. We always wanted to have a simple website with a good UX, so setting cookies for no reason wasn’t an option for us. Now, with Indiepen, we are proud to introduce a privacy-friendly alternative.
articles.title: Cookieless Alternative To Embed HTML, CSS And JS Code Snippets

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we’re talking about designing for safety. What does it mean to consider vulnerable users in our designs? Drew McLellan talks to expert Eva PenzeyMoog to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 41 With Eva PenzeyMoog: Designing For Safety

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: What exactly is HTTP/3? Why was it needed so soon after HTTP/2 (which was only finalized in 2015)? How can or should you use it? And especially, how does this improve web performance? Let’s find out.
articles.title: HTTP/3 From A To Z: Core Concepts (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: VS Code can be supercharged wuth hundreds of [VS Code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/). In this article, Leonardo shares four useful extensions that help him in his daily work.
articles.title: Four Useful VSCode Extensions For Web Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Let’s find out.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Arihant Verma)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.
articles.title: React Children And Iteration Methods

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.
articles.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you’ll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units aren’t so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework’s logic? The answer is surprisingly simple — to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of “functions”. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).
articles.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.
articles.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matthew Talebi)
articles.description: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let’s face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.
articles.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We’ve collected some useful color tools and resources that we’ve discovered lately — to help you get the most out of your creativity. We’ve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) — you might find them useful, too.
articles.title: Color Tools And Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alba Silvente)
articles.description: In this article, we will look at when it makes sense to migrate from a monolithic project to a headless setup and the benefits that come with it. In addition to a step-by-step guide on how to migrate WordPress to Storyblok Headless CMS, the problems that will arise during the process and how to deal with them.
articles.title: How To Migrate From WordPress To A Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Colby Fayock)
articles.description: By adding visual elements to your tests, you can gain more options to add meaningful ways in maintaining a high level of quality for your app. Colby Fayock explains how.
articles.title: Maintaining End-To-End Quality With Visual Testing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marcus Herrmann)
articles.description: Web app accessibility appears difficult because it seems that there is little information on the subject available online. Let’s take a closer look at the accessible use of framework features, concrete Vue.js traits, as well as community initiatives and vetted patterns.
articles.title: Three Insights I Gained While Researching Vue.js Accessibility

articles.description: There are many benefits to coding in an online IDE or code editor. With these tools you don't need to set anything up locally, you can easily share your work, and they are often free to use. In this article, you'll learn what a code editor and an IDE are.

articles.title: HTML and CSS – Inline Style, External Stylesheet, CSS Code Examples

articles.author: Sekab
articles.description:
Singleton is a widely known design pattern that generally allows you to create a global object that can be accessed from anywhere in your application and it will assure that this object will be initiated only once per lifetime of your application/code.
Before digging into why such a pattern could cause lots of problems in your codebase let us first try and implement it and imagine a use case where it would fit.
From its name a singleton is a single entity or object that would be created only once, how could we achieve something like that? how could we for example declare an object of type class A for example and disallow any other creations of instances of the same type?
Let us look at the code and discuss it further:
class Singleton {
    private static instance: Singleton;
    private co…
articles.title: Why Singletons Are Bad?

La comunidad de criptomonedas ha ido construyendo lentamente un universo alternativo donde todo está incentivado. Para cada tarea, hay un sitio o una aplicación que quiere pagarte con su token.
Sin embargo, aquí está el secreto del éxito con estos grifos: no intente maximizar sus ganancias. Úselos por lo que son. Si intentas jugar con el sistema ejecutando varias cuentas o mantienes las cosas funcionando las 24 horas del día, los 7 días de la semana, te quemarás (o te prohibirán) unos pocos dólares. Si solo los usa, se divertirá y ganará dinero sin siquiera darse cuenta. Y tampoco se apresure a retirar dinero. Reinvierte ese dinero y mantenlo. 
Entonces, sin más preámbulos, ¡veamos algunas formas de ganar criptografía gratis haciendo cosas que haces de todos modos!
¿Te gusta usar Internet?…
articles.title: 5 formas de ganar criptomonedas gratis haciendo cosas que haces de todos modos

articles.author: Massimo Artizzu
articles.description:
It's time for the final step to get our first working QR code!
If you remember the final result from the previous part, we ended up with something that had some relatively large areas in dark or light, and that might be troublesome for QR code readers:

So this final step is all about making it easier for readers to actually tell the modules apart in order to compose the square matrix. It goes something like this:
for each of the 8 estabilished masks, apply it to the matrix we got at the end of the last part;
compute the penalty score of the resulting output;
your final QR code is the one with the mask with the lowest penalty score (duh!).
Masks are, again, matrixes of dots of the same size of the QR code. Each dot has to be XOR'ed with the proto-QR code we got so far.
Fortunately we don't…
articles.title: Let's develop a QR Code Generator, part V: masking

articles.author: Francisco Mendes
articles.description:
One of the things that interested me most recently is creating a fully customized video player. Obviously, nowadays we have services that provide widgets to be used on our websites. 
Or, on the other hand, you already have dependencies that you can install and start using. But these facilities come at a price, which in this case is the absence or difficulty of customization.
That's why I had the idea of creating my own video player and apparently it's not as difficult as I had thought and in the end I found it fun.
Exactly for this reason I had the idea of writing this article, to explain step by step how to make a simple video player, but with the same logic you can go much further.
In today's example we are going to use this video, it has sound and is completely free.
Today we are not go…
articles.title: How to Create a Video Player in React

articles.author: Saurabh Kumar
articles.description:
This is part of a series of Leetcode and other curated solution explanations (index).
Leetcode Problem #1027 (Medium): Longest Arithmetic Subsequence
Given an array nums of integers, return the length of the longest arithmetic subsequence in nums.
Recall that a subsequence of an array nums is a list nums[i1], nums[i2], ..., nums[ik] with 0 <= i1 < i2 < ... < ik <= nums.length - 1, and that a sequence seq is arithmetic if seq[i+1] - seq[i] are all the same value (for 0 <= i < seq.length - 1).
Example 1:
Input: nums = [3,6,9,12]
Example 2:
Input: nums = [9,4,7,2,10]
Example 3:
Input: nums = [20,1,15,3,10,5,8]
Constraints:
2 <= nums.length <= 1000
During high-school we learnt this concept with another name **Arithmetic Progression (AP)*.
so, 1 8 15 is an AP as 1 (+7) 8 (+7) 15, we have a diff…
articles.title: Leetcode: Longest Arithmetic Subsequence

articles.author: Siddharth Venkatesh
articles.description:
Data-fetching is something I feel does not get the importance and limelight as say state management in the React world. People often combine client state and server state into their state management solution. By server state, I mean the data from your backend servers. For example, in a redux setup, client state and data from server are stored in stores and updates are handled through actions and reducers. Client state change usually causes a change in server state, so combining them makes sense in most cases. But I feel they are two separate entities and if handled properly, we can even get rid of client side state management solutions in some cases.
I started looking at solutions to separate client and server state management. Coming into the React world from an Angular background, I want…
articles.title: Cleaner data fetching with react-query

articles.author: The Jared Wilcurt
articles.description:
This list is sorted by version number, not recommendation. The TLDR is, use the latest unless you have a good reason not to, then use one of the other versions detailed here.
Remember, any time you pick an NW.js version to use, make sure your globally installed version of Node matches what is built in to NW.js. You can easily switch Node versions with one of these tools:
Linux/OSX - nvm

Windows 8+ - nvm-windows

Windows 7 - nodist





  
  
  TLDR Table of Contents



Version
Should you use




0.12.3
No. Too old, API out of date.


0.13.0
No. Newer versions offer all the same stuff


0.14.7
Only if you need to support legacy OS's, use newer version for newer OSs


0.33.4
Only if you need to do Tray app development on Win 7


0.34.0
No. Introduces Tray app bug that is fixed in 0.48.0


0…
articles.title: Guide to NW.js versions

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Under many operating systems, you can send data from from one process to another using ‘pipes’. The term ‘pipe’ is probably used by analogy with plumbing and we often use the the symbol ‘|‘ to represent a pipe (it looks like a vertical pipe). Thus, for example, you can sort a file and send it … Continue reading How fast can you pipe a large file to a C++ program?
articles.title: How fast can you pipe a large file to a C++ program?

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Researchers built a microscope that might be 10 times better than the best available microscopes. Subsidizing college education can lower earnings due to lower job experience: The Post 9/11 GI Bill (PGIB) is among the largest and most generous college subsidies enacted thus far in the U.S. (…) the introduction of the PGIB raised college … Continue reading Science and Technology links (July 31st 2021)
articles.title: Science and Technology links (July 31st 2021)

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Software developers are often concerned with the memory usage of their applications, and rightly so. Software that uses too much memory can fail, or be slow. Memory allocation will not work the same way under all systems. However, at a high level, most modern operating systems have virtual memory and physical memory (RAM). When you write … Continue reading Measuring memory usage: virtual versus real memory
articles.title: Measuring memory usage: virtual versus real memory

articles.description:
1-Sentence-Summary: The Origins of Political Order emphasizes how the historical development of political systems worldwide can be traced back to the natural inclination of humans to favor blood relationships. articles.author: Luke Rowley
articles.description:
1-Sentence-Summary: Kaizen is Japanese for “change for the better” or “continuous improvement,” and is also the title of a book by Sarah Harvey which explains this business philosophy that has expanded into the personal growth arena to give a clear pathway to reaching your goals through consistent incremental changes. Read in: 4 minutes Favorite quote […]
The post Kaizen Summary appeared first on Four Minute Books.
articles.title: Kaizen Summary

articles.author: Luke Rowley
articles.description:
1-Sentence-Summary: Bounce Back is a book by Susan Kahn, a business coach who will teach you the psychology of resilience from the perspectives of Greek philosophy, Sigmund Freud, and modern neuroscience, so you can recover quickly from professional blunders of all kinds by changing your thinking. Read in: 4 minutes Favorite quote from the author: […]
The post Bounce Back Summary appeared first on Four Minute Books.
articles.title: Bounce Back Summary

articles.author: Luke Rowley
articles.description:
1-Sentence-Summary: Socialism by Michael Newman outlines the history of the governmental theory that everything should be owned and controlled by the community as a whole, including how this idea has impacted the world in the last 200 years, how its original aims have been lost, and ways we might use it in the future. Read in: […]
The post Socialism Summary appeared first on Four Minute Books.
articles.title: Socialism Summary

articles.description:
1-Sentence-Summary: Goals! By Brian Tracy shows you how to unleash the power of goal setting to help you get or become whatever you want, identifying ways to set goals that lead you to success by being specific, challenging yourself, thinking positively, preparing, adjusting your timelines on big goals, and more. articles.description:

articles.description:

articles.description:
